title: Hubble Telescope spots interstellar comet Borisov
text:
CLOSE

Story Highlights This comet is zooming by at a blistering 110,000 mph.

It’s the second known interstellar visitor to swoop through our backyard.

The comet was discovered Aug. 30 by Gennady Borisov.

The Hubble Space Telescope observed Comet 2I/Borisov at a distance of approximately 260 million miles from Earth on Oct. 12, 2019. The comet is believed to have arrived here from another planetary system elsewhere in our galaxy. (Photo: NASA, ESA, D. Jewitt (UCLA))

Astronomers on Wednesday released the best photo yet of 2I/Borisov, the comet from outer space.

The comet, which appears blue in the image, is zooming by at a blistering 110,000 mph, and the Hubble Space Telescope caught some shots over the weekend from a distance of 260 million miles.

The comet was discovered Aug. 30 by Gennady Borisov at an observatory in Nauchnij, Crimea.

2I/Borisov is inbound toward the sun, but it will remain farther than the orbit of Mars and will approach no closer to Earth than about 190 million miles in early December, NASA said.

Looks familiar: Newly discovered comet is confirmed as an interstellar visitor – with a surprisingly familiar look

"No one knows where it came from. No one knows how long it has been drifting through the empty, cold abyss of interstellar space," NASA said in a statement Wednesday.

It’s the second known interstellar visitor to swoop through our backyard. Two years ago, a cigar-shaped rock, 'Oumuamua, paid a brief visit to our solar system.

Contributing: The Associated Press

description: Astronomers released the best photo yet of 2I/Borisov, the comet from outer space.
